6.72.text:
Thank you Zac,
and thank you for just showing once again

14.05.text:
that you have exactly the qualities of originality
and drive that will help you win in London

21.63.text:
in May
I tell you when I knew we were going to be

29.44.text:
all right in that amazing election
and it wasn’t the Ed stone

36.07.text:
the heaviest suicide note in history
or the mysterious second kitchen

41.89.text:
It was when I was walking one of those furiously
contested high streets in North West London

47.57.text:
where one week the Tory posters went up, only
to vanish next week in favour of Labour posters

53.46.text:
and we were busy restoring the Tory posters
when a shopkeeper told me that he had definitely

59.78.text:
made his mind up
and for the first time in his life he was

60.80.text:
switching right across from Labour to Tory
because he just didn’t think that Labour

68.43.text:
under Miliband would be on the side of businesses
like his

72.50.text:
and then another Asian shopkeeper said exactly
the same and then another

76.74.text:
and I was so struck that in the evening I
texted the PM – no profanities on either

83.79.text:
side, I promise
and I said: mate we are going to win this

87.92.text:
thing
And we did. We won that seat and plenty of

94.92.text:
other London seats that all the pundits said
we would lose

98.72.text:
we won in Twickenham where Tania Matthias
evicted Vince Cable

104.49.text:
we won in Kingston with James Berry, we won
in Sutton with Paul Scully

111.78.text:
we won because we had superb candidates
we won because we had a superb campaign director

120.49.text:
in Lynton Crosby – 
who seems unfortunately to have been hired

129.47.text:
by the Australian rugby team
but above all we won because of the persistence

135.09.text:
and the calm and the patience of David Cameron
and his extraordinary prime ministerial qualities

145.45.text:
that contrasted so starkly with his Labour
opponent

150.89.text:
We won because the British people did not
trust Ed Miliband to manage the economy

157.51.text:
and so it is unbelievable now to see the Labour
party has been piratically captured

166.17.text:
in a kind of social media twitstorm by what
Harold Wilson once called a small group of

172.81.text:
politically motivated men
and I know these people, my friends

177.07.text:
they are the London Labour party
trots and militants with vested interests

183.63.text:
and indeed interesting vests
They are the people who idolise Hugo Chavez

195.66.text:
and toast the revolution in taxpayer funded
vintage burgundy

199.58.text:
and I know them because we have fought and
beaten them twice

204.99.text:
and the reason I first wanted to get into
that fight eight years ago is that I am fundamentally

215.34.text:
opposed to that style of politics
They have the same ruthless methods as the

221.74.text:
old colonialists that they purport to despise
in that they believe in divide and rule

229.68.text:
Where there is a grievance, they foment it;
where there is sectarianism, they take sides

236.26.text:
Where there are racial or religious or ethnic
divisions their instinct is always to play

243.25.text:
them up
And of course there is one conflict they relish

248.37.text:
above all others, and that is economic class
war

252.30.text:
the belief that you can exalt the poor and
the needy by bashing the wealth creators

258.10.text:
imposing punitive taxation
and in the words of John Macdonnell, an avowed

263.33.text:
Marxist who is seriously putting himself forward
as the man to run the economy

270.03.text:
fermenting – sic – the destruction of
capitalism

277.44.text:
and I know there is a generation of young
people

279.63.text:
who can’t remember communism and
who think it might be a good idea to ferment

284.74.text:
anti-capitalism as if it were some fruity
alcopop

288.75.text:
and so I say to all those £3 corbynistas
– we tried that;

294.37.text:
We tried fermenting anti-capitalism in the
soviet union; we have tried brewing it in

299.50.text:
Britain in the 1970s and in many other parts
of the world

301.15.text:
and the result has been the kind of toxic
moonshine that sends you blind

306.15.text:
give that hooch a miss
We don’t believe in destroying capitalism

321.86.text:
because for all its faults capitalism is the
best means humanity has yet found of satisfying

328.40.text:
our wants and needs
We believe in using capitalism to deliver

334.13.text:
social and economic progress
and we do it in a one nation way – by bringing

341.27.text:
people together
and I hesitate to return to the rugby but

347.23.text:
I am afraid there is a lesson in that agonizing
match at Twickenham the other night

351.44.text:
and I speak as someone whose happiest formative
afternoons were spent as a tight head prop

357.22.text:
– the guy on the right
and apart from grunting and heaving the crucial

365.45.text:
thing you have to do as a tight head – in
fact just about the only thing you have to

370.60.text:
do apart from grunting and trying to stop
the other guy sticking his fingers up your

375.97.text:
nose
is to bind on tightly and correctly – in

382.16.text:
my case to the hooker
(insert joke here, as Jeremy Corbyn’s autocue

393.02.text:
would say)
and it is the

404.41.text:
rugby scrum that provides a metaphor for my
political beliefs

408.48.text:
because our lives are really a gigantic collective
effort

416.03.text:
in which one person’s bulk makes up for
another person’s slightness of stature

421.40.text:
and where everyone is so tightly bound together
that one person’s forward progress drives

426.96.text:
another person’s forward progress
and that is the society we need – not just

432.48.text:
a big society, but a united society
where the different elements are bound together

440.68.text:
by an irreducible set of values
democracy and freedom and equality under the

446.50.text:
law
and let no one say these ideas are trite,

449.04.text:
or trivial
– not in a Britain where men and women are

453.80.text:
now being segregated at university societies
and where

458.42.text:
young girls are suffering the abomination
of female genital mutilation

463.33.text:
and I applaud those two fantastic London MPs
Justine Greening and Jane Ellison for their

469.53.text:
campaign against a vice that has been tolerated
for too long in the name of political correctness

481.85.text:
I want a Britain united by command of the
English language

490.92.text:
When I meet people who have been here for
decades – very often women - without learning

497.76.text:
this essential tool of economic participation
I think it is not just a failure to integrate

504.26.text:
but a kind of oppression
the logical consequence of the politically

508.53.text:
correct multicultural loony-ism of the left
and if dear Jezza is wondering whether to

516.08.text:
sing the national anthem
can I recommend that he comes to City Hall

521.02.text:
for our annual citizenship ceremony
where people from around the world queue to

526.55.text:
have a selfie – not with me, but with a
picture on an easel

533.29.text:
of the queen
not because of who she is or what she has

538.54.text:
done in the last 63 years – extraordinary
record of service though that is

543.43.text:
but because of what she represents – the
continuity of the great free institutions

557.75.text:
of this country
the ideas that she incarnates:

561.54.text:
of our democracy and of the sovereignty of
the crown in parliament

566.32.text:
and if people are to be loyal to those ideas
then it is vital that our democracy is healthy,

572.85.text:
and vibrant, and truly representative
and that means getting the right deal now

580.48.text:
from our EU partners
as I know David Cameron can

585.94.text:
helping to restore trust in parliament by
making sure that new laws affecting the British

593.67.text:
public are made by people the British public
can kick out at elections

599.84.text:
and it should be up to this parliament and
this country – not to Jean-Claude Juncker

604.54.text:
– to decide if too many people are coming
here

607.78.text:
because it is not that we object to immigration
in itself – I speak as the proud great grandson

626.44.text:
of a Turk who fled his country in fear of
his life

635.96.text:
to Wimbledon for some reason
(and who was then assassinated by his political

648.09.text:
opponents – a fate I intend to avoid)
It is about who decides; it is about who is

660.32.text:
ultimately responsible; it is about control
and you will loosen the bonds that should

665.64.text:
unite society if people feel that their elected
politicians have abdicated their ability to

672.60.text:
control those things that ought frankly to
be within their power

678.39.text:
And when you look at what is happening in
Greece, where economic independence is being

684.57.text:
sacrificed on the altar of the euro
you could not say that democracy in Europe

689.36.text:
was in good health
and we should be sticking up for it, as we

692.48.text:
have in the last hundred years
because those are our values

696.41.text:
shared language, shared cultural assumptions
shared confidence in our political institutions

704.38.text:
These are the ties that unite our society
– and yet they are not powerful enough on

711.79.text:
their own
if the economic gap between us is allowed

717.17.text:
to grow too big
and even though I am still just about the

720.38.text:
only politician to speak out in favour of
bankers

730.80.text:
I say we one nation Tories cannot ignore the
gulf in pay packets that yawns wider year

736.88.text:
by year
In 1980 a chief executive of a FTSE 100 company

740.24.text:
earned about 25 times the average pay – the
average pay – of his or her employees

747.04.text:
What do you think the multiple is today? 130
times; and there are some who pay themselves

765.25.text:
780 times
and again I believe that people will accept

774.69.text:
this, but only on certain conditions
only if they feel that this dynamic, entrepreneurial,

785.45.text:
high-reward capitalist system is actually
helping to take everyone forward…

791.12.text:
We will accept it
if and only if they pay their taxes – rich

794.67.text:
corporations and individuals
if and only if those firms are paying their

804.55.text:
employees decently – and it is great that
a giant retailer like Lidl is paying not just

808.83.text:
the minimum wage but the London Living Wage
and we must ensure that as we reform welfare

814.10.text:
and we cut taxes that we protect the hardest
working and lowest paid

818.81.text:
the retail staff, the cleaners, who get up
in the small hours or work through the night

824.68.text:
because they have dreams for what their families
can achieve

829.94.text:
the people without whom the London economy
would simply collapse

834.75.text:
the aspiring, striving, working people 
that Labour is leaving behind

848.42.text:
and then there is an even more important requirement
If people are to feel bound in to this united

853.41.text:
society there must be opportunity
and it is the Tory policies

859.10.text:
on housing – more new homes now being built
in London than in any year for 35 years

864.50.text:
on transport – the biggest programme of
infrastructure since queen Victoria

868.25.text:
on education – the schools revolution epitomised
by Katharine Birbalsingh’s amazing times-table

874.63.text:
spouting and Shakespeare reciting school in
Brent

878.80.text:
that are creating opportunity…
Take those policies together with our natural

886.14.text:
instincts to cut taxes, cut red tape, to help
business and enterprise

892.26.text:
and you can see why there has been a jobs
boom in London, with youth unemployment at

898.73.text:
its lowest level for 25 years
and 400,000 people lifted out of poverty in

904.65.text:
London since I have been Mayor
and the point I make to our crusty friends

916.64.text:
outside is that it is actually sensible one
nation policies in London have been disproportionately

926.25.text:
beneficial for the poorest
If crime hits the poorest hardest – and

934.70.text:
it does - then it follows that is the poor
who have most to gain from falls in crime

943.52.text:
If you are poor in London, you are more likely
to send your kids to a school where the air

950.40.text:
is polluted
if you are poor, your kids are 40 per cent

956.19.text:
more likely to die or be seriously injured
in a road traffic accident

961.72.text:
if you are poor your kids are far more likely
to die in a domestic fire

966.67.text:
and so if you reduce all those evils as we
have, in the last eight years

972.59.text:
– crime down almost 20 per cent,
– murder rate down 50 per cent,

976.19.text:
– air pollution down 20 pc for NOX and 15
pc for particulates,

978.12.text:
– deaths on the road down 40 per cent,
– deaths from fire down 50 per cent

982.32.text:
then you are doing something for fairness
and for social justice

986.89.text:
and let me give you this final knock-out point,
for all those who think inequality has increased

1002.83.text:
there is one simple way in which we have a
more united society – and that is in our

1009.05.text:
ability to spend more time on this earth in
good health with our families

1016.17.text:
just since I have been mayor, life expectancy
has gone up in London by 18 months for women

1023.99.text:
and 19 months for men –
and there are parts of the Harrow Road where

1029.60.text:
life expectancy at birth is now 97
I don’t know what monkey glands or royal

1034.84.text:
jelly they apply in the Harrow road but
you live longer under the Tories, my friends

1041.00.text:
and yet the most extraordinary and counter-intuitive
statistic is that it is the poorest who are

1055.35.text:
seeing the biggest gains, so that the gap
in average life expectancy between rich and

1063.74.text:
poor has diminished from about five years
when I became mayor to about 3 years today

1071.61.text:
and of course it is disgraceful that there
is still a gap at all; but that is social

1079.65.text:
justice, that is progress
that is what we are fighting for

1084.35.text:
I am immensely proud of what has been achieved
in the last seven and a half years under a

1091.58.text:
Tory mayoralty
and I thank my brilliant and indomitable team,

1097.31.text:
so many of whom are here in this hall led
by my irrepressible chief of staff sir Edward

1103.51.text:
lister
3 of them now my fellow MPs – Kit, Victoria,

1119.52.text:
James
we began with a financial crisis that many

1126.71.text:
people said would knock London off its perch
as the world’s financial capital

1131.76.text:
and we come to the final furlongs with London
the number one capital for banking, for bioscience,

1137.94.text:
for media, for culture, for theatre
and with our capital installed for the second

1145.12.text:
year running the world’s top tourist destination
with 18.8m international visitors , knocking

1148.71.text:
Paris and New York off the number one spot
the world’s most popular city – under

1155.81.text:
the Conservatives
We have upgraded the tube so massively that

1166.66.text:
it is carrying 25 per cent more passengers
than when I was elected - every day

1174.39.text:
and that is because we have cut delays by
more than 50 per cent

1179.36.text:
we are delivering Crossrail on time and on
budget, the biggest engineering project in

1183.81.text:
Europe
we have not only staged the world’s greatest

1187.84.text:
ever Olympic games but we have secured a sensational
physical legacy at the Olympic park in Stratford

1194.83.text:
so that London is now the only Olympic city
to have found a long term private sector future

1200.59.text:
for all 7 sporting venues
to say nothing of the new V and A and the

1218.33.text:
first ever Smithsonian museum outside the
USA;

1225.46.text:
Around the clock from Old Oak to Enfield to
Stratford to Greenwich to Croydon to Battersea

1229.89.text:
we are seeing this city rebuilt and regenerated
on a scale not achieved for centuries

1236.50.text:
and we are doing it in a way that is sensitive
to the environment and that improves quality

1243.05.text:
of life
we have introduced new bikes and cleaner buses;

1252.39.text:
we have got 100s of 1000s of Londoners volunteering
through Team London; and they are mentoring

1259.99.text:
kids and planting thousands of trees
and in spite of this frenzy of activity we

1270.56.text:
done the Tory thing
we have cut council tax by 27 per cent

1280.59.text:
and it is wonderful now to see the London
agenda being rolled out across the country

1292.98.text:
- fiscal devolution, with our great English
cities free to spend the business rates they

1301.61.text:
raise
- a new National Living wage

1304.54.text:
- pooling pension funds (as we have done with
Lancashire) to create a half billion pound

1310.87.text:
sovereign wealth fund for infrastructure
- new rules on strike ballots to stop hardworking

1316.47.text:
people being held to ransom by a tiny minority
in fact the only type of crime currently going

1325.32.text:
up is the theft of City Hall policies – a
crime I entirely condone

1335.45.text:
and we are not done yet, as we come now to
what we call operation juddering climax

1342.55.text:
we will defeat the haters of beauty and instal
a garden Bridge

1349.99.text:
we will extend the northern line to Battersea
– or the Wandsworth powerhouse, as it is

1355.50.text:
probably now called in the Treasury
we will get a night tube

1362.63.text:
and thanks to the support of the Prime Minister
and the Chancellor I am confident that we

1366.82.text:
will get Crossrail 2 in the ground by the
end of the next decade

1371.21.text:
because you can’t be a builder in London
without Crossrail 2

1377.93.text:
and if we are going to build new airport capacity
let’s not bodge it with one runway in the

1390.32.text:
wrong place
in a short termist and environmentally disastrous

1398.01.text:
solution
- one of the many things on which I agree

1402.09.text:
with Zac
and let’s compete with every other major

1405.34.text:
economy, from Germany to France to Spain to
Holland to India to every Gulf state to Turkey

1408.91.text:
to China
and do the job properly this time round

1412.43.text:
in this confident and progressive generation
with the hub airport we will need for the

1417.63.text:
country that most forecasts believe will overtake
Germany, by 2050, to be the largest, the most

1423.78.text:
powerful and the most dynamic economy in Europe
So much done; so much to look forward to

1444.73.text:
Are we going to fumble and knock the ball
forward beneath the feet of our political

1451.11.text:
foes?
what an enemy, my friends

1453.51.text:
As I came into the conference area yesterday
we had to go through a kind of Khyber pass

1461.77.text:
with protestors on either side hurling eggs
and water bombs

1465.63.text:
perhaps some of you had the same experience
were we intimidated?

1474.89.text:
no
will we give up our plans to take this country

1481.06.text:
Will we surrender to the hard-left agitators
– supported by Jeremy Corbyn – who believe

1487.24.text:
in these tactics and want to divide this society?
No

1491.89.text:
In fact I drew only one conclusion – that
we need to do more to encourage sport in schools,

1504.97.text:
because they managed to miss their target
with every projectile

1521.80.text:
just as Labour has missed the lesson of that
election victory in May

1527.84.text:
because it wasn’t just about rejecting Miliband
and Salmond and Sturgeon and all the other

1531.22.text:
fishy characters
it was because they believe that if they stick

1542.92.text:
with us then this country could be on the
verge of something great

1550.52.text:
and they see the difference between Tories
and the extreme left

1556.12.text:
the extreme left is always willing to believe
the worst about this country and its history

1562.90.text:
and its institutions
it is we Tories who are always ready to believe

1568.94.text:
the best about the British people, what we
stand for and what we can do

1573.89.text:
and that is why I am a Conservative, a one-nation
conservative

1579.95.text:
and as we drive for the line in the last eight
months of this mayoralty

1593.20.text:
with the ball at our feet
I want us all to work together to get Zac

1603.02.text:
Goldsmith elected for four more years of solid
progressive one nation conservative government

1612.00.text:
in London
with a party united in our ambition to unite

1618.65.text:
our society
Thank you all very much
